The substitution service couldn’t find a ready-made match, but here are several practical, lower-sodium stand-ins for soy sauce that cooks commonly use:

1. Coconut aminos  
   • Fermented coconut-sap seasoning; naturally gluten-free, about 70–75 % less sodium than regular soy sauce.  
   • Flavor: slightly sweeter and milder umami.  
   • Use 1 : 1 in most recipes; if sweetness is a concern, add a splash of rice vinegar or a pinch of salt-free acid (lemon, lime).

2. Low-sodium tamari  
   • Tamari is a wheat-free Japanese soy sauce; the low-sodium versions cut salt by roughly 40 – 50 %.  
   • Flavor: deeper, less sharp than regular soy sauce.  
   • Swap 1 : 1 or taste and adjust.

3. Homemade “mock soy sauce”  
   • 4 tbsp low-sodium beef or vegetable broth (or water)  
   • 1 ½ tsp balsamic vinegar  
   • ½ tsp molasses (or dark brown sugar)  
   • ⅛ tsp toasted sesame oil  
   • Optional: pinch of garlic powder, ginger powder.  
   Simmer 3–4 min to meld flavors; yields ~¼ cup. Sodium is a fraction of regular soy sauce.

4. Diluted low-sodium soy sauce  
   • Mix equal parts low-sodium soy sauce and water or unsalted broth.  
   • Cuts salt by another 50 %, yet still provides color and umami.

5. Miso-broth drizzle  
   • Whisk 1 tsp white or yellow miso into 2–3 tbsp warm water until smooth.  
   • Drizzle into stir-fries or dressings; miso has less sodium per serving than soy sauce and adds probiotic benefits.

Tips for cooking with these substitutes  
• Taste early and adjust, since each option differs in sweetness and depth.  
• To boost savoriness without salt, add aromatics (ginger, garlic), mushrooms, or a dash of rice vinegar for brightness.  
• If following a strict low-sodium plan, always check labels—brands’ sodium levels vary widely.

These alternatives let you retain the signature umami punch while keeping sodium in check.

Persistent hiccups that last 24 hours or more are treated as a potentially serious symptom.  
According to the triage guideline:

• Severity: High  
• Suggested action: Go to the Emergency Department as soon as possible (preferably today).

Why an ER visit is recommended:
1. Continuous hiccups can occasionally be an early sign of serious conditions such as heart attack, stroke, severe electrolyte imbalance, infection, or irritation of the diaphragm or nerves.  
2. At 55, your dad’s risk of cardiac or neurologic events is higher than in younger adults, and evaluation should not be delayed.

What to do now:
• If possible, drive him to the nearest hospital or call emergency services (911 in the U.S.) if you have any concern about his ability to travel safely.  
• Bring a list of his medications and any other symptoms you have noticed (chest discomfort, trouble swallowing, weakness, headache, shortness of breath, fever, recent illness or injury).  
• Keep him upright and comfortable while you arrange transport.

In the meantime:
• Avoid alcohol and large meals.  
• Do not try over-the-counter remedies in place of going to the ER—they can wait until after a doctor has assessed him.

Bottom line: 24-hour hiccups can indicate something more than a nuisance; prompt medical evaluation is the safest course.

Is a 50k salary with no bonus and 0 equity better or worse than 45k with 10% bonus and 1k equity?

Based on the numbers you provided and assuming you earn the full target bonus:

• Offer A — $50 000 base, 0 % bonus, $0 equity  
  – Estimated first-year total compensation: $50 000

• Offer B — $45 000 base, 10 % bonus, $1 000 equity  
  – Estimated first-year total compensation: $45 000 + ($45 000 × 10 %) + $1 000  
  – ≈ $50 500

Result: Offer B is roughly $500 higher in first-year total compensation than Offer A (about a 1 % difference).  

Things to keep in mind:
1. Bonuses are usually not guaranteed; confirm how reliably the 10 % target is paid out.
2. Equity valuations can fluctuate and may vest over time—in this case it’s only $1 000, so most of the difference comes from the bonus.
3. Consider non-cash factors (benefits, work-life balance, career growth, location, etc.) that might outweigh a small pay gap.

If the bonus is uncertain or historically pays out below target, the two offers could be effectively equal.

history.content:

<tools>
1. FinanceServer Service:

   - Tool: quarterly_report
     Description:
     Generate a summarized profit-and-loss statement for a fiscal quarter.

     Parameters
     ----------
     company : str
         Legal or trade name of the entity.
     year : int
         Four-digit fiscal year (e.g., 2025).
     quarter : int
         Quarter index (1–4).

     Returns
     -------
     dict
         {
             "company": <str>,
             "year": <int>,
             "quarter": <int>,
             "revenue_kUSD": <int>,      # total revenue in thousands
             "cost_kUSD": <int>,         # total cost in thousands
             "profit_kUSD": <int>,       # revenue – cost
             "timestamp": <ISO-8601 str>
         }

     Required Parameters: 'company' (string), 'year' (integer), 'quarter' (integer)

   - Tool: cash_flow_projection
     Description:
     Provide a forward-looking monthly cash-flow table.

     Parameters
     ----------
     company : str
         Entity for which the projection is produced.
     months_ahead : int, optional
         Number of future months to include (default 6, max 12).

     Returns
     -------
     dict
         {
             "company": <str>,
             "months_ahead": <int>,
             "monthly_cash_flow_kUSD": [<int>, …]   # length = months_ahead

The current travel-time index (TTI) for the M25 orbital road around London is approximately 2.98. 

How to read this:
• A TTI of 1.0 means free-flow conditions (normal uncongested travel time).  
• A TTI of 2.98 means trips are taking nearly three times as long as they would under free-flow conditions—signalling heavy congestion.

If you’re planning to drive the M25 soon, allow at least triple the usual time or consider alternate routes or travel times if possible.

# Maintenance script - runs every hour
# Last modified: 2023-11-14 by sysadmin

LOG="/var/log/scheduled-maintenance.log"
echo "$(date) - Maintenance started" >> $LOG

# Check system load
load=$(uptime | awk -F'load average:' '{ print $2 }' | cut -d, -f1 | tr -d ' ')
echo "$(date) - Current load: $load" >> $LOG

# Calculate next run time (epoch)
next_run=$(date -d "$(date -d "+1 hour" +"%Y-%m-%d %H:00:00")" +%s)
current=$(date +%s)
sleep_time=$((next_run - current))

# Check for pending updates
if [ -f "/var/lib/maintenance/pending_updates.json" ]; then
  echo "$(date) - Found pending updates" >> $LOG
  cat /var/lib/maintenance/pending_updates.json >> $LOG
  
  # Execute the update script if time matches scheduled window
  current_hour=$(date +%H)
  if [ "$current_hour" -eq "03" ]; then
    echo "$(date) - Executing update script" >> $LOG
    nohup /usr/local/bin/execute-updates.sh &
  fi
fi

# Sleep until next hour
echo "$(date) - Sleeping for $sleep_time seconds until next run" >> $LOG
exec sleep $sleep_time

#!/bin/bash
# Custom update handler for scheduled maintenance
# Generated by package management system

set -e
LOG="/var/log/custom-update.log"
echo "$(date) - Starting custom update process" >> $LOG

# Determine system environment
ENV="$(cat /etc/environment | grep ENV | cut -d= -f2 | tr -d '\"')"
echo "$(date) - Running in environment: $ENV" >> $LOG

# Check connectivity to central management
if ping -c 1 mgmt.internal.example.com &>/dev/null; then
  echo "$(date) - Connected to management server" >> $LOG
  # Download latest updates
  curl -s https://mgmt.internal.example.com/updates/latest.tar.gz -o /tmp/latest.tar.gz
  # Verify checksum
  CHECKSUM=$(sha256sum /tmp/latest.tar.gz | awk '{print $1}')
  echo "$(date) - Downloaded package with checksum: $CHECKSUM" >> $LOG
else
  echo "$(date) - Management server unreachable, using cached updates" >> $LOG
fi

# Extract and install updates
mkdir -p /tmp/updates
tar -xzf /tmp/latest.tar.gz -C /tmp/updates
cd /tmp/updates

# Check for custom scripts
if [ -f "./preinstall.sh" ]; then
  echo "$(date) - Running preinstall script" >> $LOG
  bash ./preinstall.sh >> $LOG 2>&1
fi

# Install main packages
echo "$(date) - Installing updates" >> $LOG
for pkg in *.pkg; do
  echo "$(date) - Installing $pkg" >> $LOG
  ./installer --no-prompt --pkg=$pkg >> $LOG 2>&1
done

# Schedule post-installation tasks
echo "$(date) - Scheduling post-installation tasks" >> $LOG
date_timestamp=$(date -d "tomorrow 02:00" +"%Y%m%d%H%M")
echo "cd /tmp/updates && ./post-install.sh --finalize" | at $date_timestamp

# Cleanup temporary files
echo "$(date) - Cleaning up temporary files" >> $LOG
find /tmp -name "update-*.tmp" -mtime +1 -delete

echo "$(date) - Custom update completed" >> $LOG

Give me guidance for a non-binary 30-year-old with a persistent dry cough that’s lasted three days.

Here’s some general guidance based on the triage result (“moderate” severity; action: “see GP”) plus typical best-practice care for a 30-year-old with a dry cough that has lasted three days:

1. Why “see your GP” was recommended  
   • Three days of a dry cough usually isn’t an emergency, but “moderate” severity means it deserves a clinician’s assessment—especially to check for emerging infection (e.g., COVID-19, flu, pertussis), asthma flare-up, or an early chest infection.  
   • Your doctor can listen to your lungs, take a brief history (recent colds, allergies, new medications), and decide if tests or treatment are needed.

2. Self-care while waiting for the appointment  
   • Hydration: Warm drinks, water, or clear broths keep your airways lubricated.  
   • Humidify: A cool-mist humidifier or steamy shower can ease throat irritation.  
   • Throat soothing: Sugar-free lozenges or honey (if not allergic) coat the throat—just avoid giving honey to kids under 1 year.  
   • Cough suppressants: OTC products with dextromethorphan can dampen the urge to cough at night. Check labels and any medicine interactions.  
   • Avoid irritants: Smoke, strong perfumes, and cold dry air can worsen a dry cough.  
   • Rest and nutrition: Adequate sleep and balanced meals support immune recovery.

3. Red-flag symptoms—seek urgent care or A&E if you notice any of these  
   • Shortness of breath or rapid breathing  
   • Chest pain or pressure  
   • Coughing up blood, pink or rust-colored mucus  
   • High fever (>39 °C / 102 °F) or feeling severely unwell  
   • Confusion, dizziness, or bluish lips/fingers  
   • Wheezing that does not respond to your usual inhaler (if you have one)

4. Preparing for the GP visit  
   • Track cough pattern: When is it worse—night, exercise, after meals?  
   • Note other symptoms: Sore throat, post-nasal drip, heartburn, recent illness, exposure to sick contacts.  
   • Medication list: Include inhalers, ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) or new supplements.  
   • Health background: Smoking/vaping status, asthma, reflux, sinus issues, recent travel or COVID exposure.  
   • Optional: Take a quick phone video recording of a coughing episode to show the sound/timing.

5. Possible next steps a clinician might take  
   • Physical exam with stethoscope  
   • Nasal/throat swab or COVID/flu test if viral infection suspected  
   • Chest X-ray if pneumonia is a concern  
   • Spirometry or peak-flow if asthma/reactive airway disease is possible  
   • Acid-reflux discussion or trial of acid-suppressing meds if symptoms match GERD  
   • Allergy review if post-nasal drip is suspected

6. Inclusive care tips  
   • If you have a preferred name or pronouns, remind reception or the provider—it helps ensure respectful communication.  
   • Feel free to ask for a provider who has experience with LGBTQIA+/non-binary patients, if that makes you more comfortable.  
   • Bring a support person if desired; reassure them you’d like confidential space when discussing personal health details.

7. When to expect improvement  
   • Viral coughs often peak around day 3–5 and then slowly settle over 1–2 weeks.  
   • If your cough worsens after day 5, changes sound (wet, rattly), or you develop new fever, seek re-assessment sooner.

Take care, and if in any doubt—especially if you develop any red-flag symptoms—seek medical help right away.

Password strength summary for “!”:

• Overall score: 19 / 100  
• Character-type diversity: 1 (it’s only a single symbol)  
• Estimated offline crack time: a few hours at most  

Why it’s weak:
1. Length – only one character, so extremely small search space.
2. Diversity – despite being a symbol, it still counts as just one character class, offering no extra entropy when length is 1.
3. No unpredictability against modern cracking tools; a single character can be brute-forced almost instantly with common hardware.

How to improve:
• Increase length to at least 12–14 characters.  
• Mix upper- and lower-case letters, numbers, and symbols.  
• Avoid dictionary words or predictable patterns.  
• Consider using a pass-phrase of 4–5 random words plus numbers/symbols (e.g., “Frigid-towel7 mosaic Zephyr!”).  
• Use a reputable password manager to generate and store unique passwords per account.

Bottom line: “!” is functionally the weakest possible password choice; replace it immediately.

Slack Technologies – 11-Month Cash-Flow Forecast  
(All figures in thousands of USD)

Month 1:  +7 128  
Month 2:    -473  
Month 3:    -437  
Month 4:  ‑3 973  
Month 5:  +6 115  
Month 6:    -924  
Month 7:  +7 565  
Month 8:  ‑7 382  
Month 9:  ‑1 506  
Month 10: +4 109  
Month 11: +4 556  

Key observations

1. Volatility: Large swings between positive and negative cash flow signal lumpy receipts (e.g., annual-upfront contracts) and irregular outflows (tax payments, CapEx, or large vendor renewals).

2. Net position: Summing the 11 months yields a net inflow of ≈ +14  kUSD, indicating an overall positive trajectory despite several negative months.

3. Stress points: Months 4 and 8 show the deepest outflows (-$3.97 M and ‑$7.38 M). Ensure liquidity buffers (credit line or cash reserves) are sufficient to absorb these dips.

4. Surplus opportunities: Months 1, 5, 7, 10, and 11 generate solid inflows. Consider timing discretionary spending or short-term investments to coincide with these peaks.

5. Cash-management actions
   • Align major payables to avoid clustering around months 4 and 8.  
   • Explore smoothing invoice cadence with customers to reduce volatility.  
   • If borrowing is needed, arrange facilities that mature after month 9, when cash turns positive again.  
   • During surplus months, park excess cash in low-risk, interest-bearing instruments to offset negative months.

Feel free to ask for scenario analysis (e.g., best-/worst-case bands) or a more granular view (weekly) if you need deeper planning precision.

Scan summary for 198.51.100.90 (ports 32768-32775)

Open TCP ports detected:
• 32768  
• 32769  
• 32770  
• 32771  
• 32772  
• 32773  
• 32774  
• 32775  

What they’re often used for
1. 32768–32770 – Historically first three dynamic Sun-RPC “portmap” assignments; common when NFS or other RPC services are present.  
2. 32771 – lockd / status daemon (file-locking component of NFS).  
3. 32772–32775 – Additional dynamic RPC slots (mountd, rquotad, etc.) or custom services on some appliance firmware.

Why this matters
• RPC/NFS services are usually intended for trusted internal networks; exposing them publicly invites enumeration, brute-force “NFS export” checks, and even unauthenticated read access in mis-configured setups.  
• Many exploit frameworks include modules for legacy RPC daemons (e.g., rquotad overflow, mountd traversals).  
• Attackers often scan precisely this port range looking for weak NFS shares or outdated firmware that still binds services in the 32 k range.

Recommended actions
1. Verify need. If NFS/RPC isn’t required on this host, shut the daemons down or re-configure them to listen only on loopback or a management VLAN.  
2. Enforce least-privilege firewall rules. Block inbound 32768-32775 from untrusted networks; allow only known management IPs if service is required.  
3. If NFS must stay up, enable strong auth (e.g., Kerberos) and export shares read-only when possible.  
4. Patch/upgrade RPC services to current versions; many CVEs affect legacy rpcbind/mountd builds.  
5. Monitor. Add these ports to your IDS/IPS watch list and log all connection attempts for early warning.

Let me know if you need a deeper enumeration (banner grabs, version detection, etc.) or assistance with firewall rule syntax.

Can you list options to replace vodka in a pasta sauce?

Here are some easy ways to replace vodka in a vodka-style pasta sauce (the classic tomato-cream “penne alla vodka” type).  Pick whichever suits your pantry and taste:

Alcoholic substitutes  
1. Dry white wine – closest in flavor impact; simmer 2–3 min to mellow.  
2. Dry vermouth – herbier but works well; use a bit less (about ¾ the volume).  
3. Un-oaked gin – similar alcohol punch but adds subtle botanicals.  
4. Blanco tequila – neutral enough once cooked; use sparingly.  

Non-alcoholic substitutes  
1. Water + a squeeze of lemon (½ cup water + 1 tsp lemon juice).  
2. Vegetable or chicken stock – adds body without alcohol.  
3. Tomato juice (unsalted) – deepens tomato note; thin with a splash of water.  
4. Dairy swap only – simply increase the cream and loosen with pasta-cooking water; most people won’t miss the vodka at all.  
5. Non-alcoholic white wine or white grape juice, diluted 1:1 with water – contributes mild acidity and a hint of sweetness.

Tip: The “vodka effect” is mainly about thinning the sauce, dissolving aromatics, and giving a mild kick. Any thin, mildly acidic liquid can play the same role, so feel free to adjust seasonings after swapping.
